en: 25 Creative Europe MEDIA-funded films at Cannes Film Festival 13-24 May
The 68th Cannes Film Festival, will be held 13-24 May with a record number of 25 Creative Europe MEDIA-backed films in the different selections.
25 Creative Europe MEDIA-funded films at Cannes Film Festival 13-24 May
57-Web home page (text, logo, image of a department)
From 13-24 May, the 68th edition of one of the key dates in the cinematic calendar, Cannes Film Festival, will be held in France with 23 Creative Europe-backed films featuring.

Creative Europe, through its MEDIA sub-programme, supports European cinema and these are represented across categories this year at Cannes.

In Competition - competing for Palme d'Or , projected in the Théâtre Lumière

  • La Tête Haute - a French production by Emmanuelle Bercot about a boy, abandoned and in trouble with the law.
  • Erran (aka Dheepan) - a French production by Jacques Audiard about a Tamil Tiger who flees Sri Lanka only to find more conflict awaiting him in Paris.
  • Marguerite et Julien - a French production by Valérie Donzelli, a contemporary fairytale about desire, passion, hope, love and death.
  • Il racconto dei racconti (Tale of Tales) - UK/French/Italian co-production by Matteo Garrone based on the gothic novel of the same name.
  • Carol - A British production by Todd Haynes, the story of two women who fall in love in 1950s' New York.
  • Macbeth - Justin Kurzel's British production of Shakespeare's Scottish masterpiece.
  • The Lobster - Yorgos Lanthimos's co-production (Ireland, UK, France, Spain, Netherlands) is a love story set in a near future where singles are persecuted.
  • Mon Roi - From director Maïwenn, a French production of a woman overcoming her turbulent past.
  • Mia Madre - Nanni Morretti brings us the story of a director trying to balance shooting and family life in this Franco-Italian production.
  • La Giovinezza (Youth) - By Paolo Sorrentino, this co-production (Italy/UK/Switzerland/France) tells the story of Mick and Fred, two old friends on vacation in the Alps.
  • Louder Than Bombs - Joachim Trier's co-production (Norway, France, Denmark) is a hypnotic and exhilerating picture of a family brought together by death.

Un Certain Regard - dedicated to daring and innovative productions

  • Zvizdan (The High Sun) - This Croatian/Slovenia/Serbian production from Dalibor Matanic is a story about the dangers and strengths of foribben love in the Balkans.
  • Un Etaj Mai Jos (One floor below) - Radu Muntean's Romanian film is the tale of Patrascu, the sole unfortunate witness of a domestic quarrel that ends up in a murder.

Out of Competition - projected in the Théâtre Lumière but not competing

  • The Little Prince (Le Petit Prince) - From Mark Osborne (UK), comes the first-ever animated feature film adaptation of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s literary masterpiece.

Special Screenings - special opportunities to view more personal works

  • Amnesia - This Franco-Swiss film by Barbet Schroeder looks at the experiences of Jo and Martha in the early days of Ibiza's techno revloution.
  • Une Histoire de Fou (Don't tell me the Boy was Mad) - Robert Guédiguian's French production tells the story of a bomber reunited with his accidental victim.

Midnight Screenings - late-night viewings of special personal works

  • Amy (Untitled Amy Winehouse Documentary) - A British documentary by Asif Kapadia on the late soul singer using previously unseen archive footage.
  • Love - Gaspar Noé's British sexual melodrama about a boy and a girl and another girl. It's a love story, which celebrates sex in a joyous way.

Cannes Classics

  • Orson Welles: Autopsie d'une légende - Elisabeth Kapnist's French documentary looks at some of the enigma's of multi-talented Orson Welles's film career.
  • Jag Är Ingrid (Ingrid Bergman - In Her own Words) - This Swedish documentary by Stig Björkman is a personal portrait of the great actress Ingrid Bergman.

La Semaine de la Critique - parallel section focusing on emerging talent

  • Ni le ciel ni la Terre - A French film from Clément Cogitore takes us to a remote Afghan valley with a squad of troops in the late stages of the war.

Directors' Fortnight - non-competitive parallel section for emerging directors

  • A perfect day - Fernando León de Aranoa's Spanish film is the tale of Sophie, an aid worker, struggling to save the water supply of an abandoned community.
  • As mil e uma noites (Arabian Nights) - Miguel Gomes's film (Germany/ Portugal, France/Switzerland) recasts the Arabian classic in present-day Portugal in the midst of socio-economic crisis.
  • L'ombre des femmes (In the shadow of women) - Philippe Garrel's French production tells the story of Pierre, a struggling documentary film-maker, caught between two women in a tangle of love and infidelity.
  • Le tout nouveau testament (The Brand New Testament) - A co-production from Belgium, France and Luxembourg, Jaco Van Dormael's film is a a surreal comedy in which God is a real-life character who lives in Brussels.
